CatDescriptText: Mrs. Melba Byrd, salesgirl, Homewood and Mrs. Bernice Williams, housewife, Hill, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 31, 1962, pg. A3  with question: "Should relief payments to unemployed persons be increased?" Mrs. Byrd's answer reads: "Definitely, I can see for myself from the people I know who are on it.  They need more because they aren't getting enough to live decently."  Mrs. Williams' answer reads: "I think so.  I know when my husband got his check, it wasn't even enough for us to meet our bills."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Melba Byrd wearing leather jacket with toggles, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Group portrait of two women, including Bernice Williams on left wearing light colored coat with two large buttons and hat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
